metadata.title: Evaluation of folic acid release from spray dried powder particles of pectin-whey protein nano-capsules

sections.text:
Our main goal was to evaluate release kinetics of nano-encapsulated folic acid within a double W1/O/W2 emulsion. First, W1/O nano-emulsions loaded with folic acid were prepared and reemulsified into an aqueous phase (W2) containing single whey protein concentrate (WPC) layer or double layer complex of WPC-pectin to form W1/O/W2 emulsions. Final double emulsions were spray dried and their microstructure was analyzed in terms of scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). Also the release trends of folic acid were determined and fitted with experimental models of zero and first order, Higuchi, and HixsonCrowell. It was revealed that folic acid nano-capsules made with Span as the surfactant had the lowest release rate in acidic conditions (pH=4) and highest release in the alkaline conditions (pH=11). The best model fitting for folic acid release data was observed for single layer WPC encapsulated powders with the highest R2. Our FTIR data showed there was no chemical interaction between WPC and pectin in double layered capsules and based on SEM results, single WPC layered capsules resulted in smooth and uniform particles which by incorporating pectin, some wrinkles and shrinkage were found in the surface of spray dried powder particles.
Keywords: Release; Nano-encapsulation; Folic acid.
1. Introduction
Bioactive components such as vitamins are susceptible to breakdown: easily release, rapidly eliminate from the body, have little absorption in the gastrointestinal tract and are influenced by processing/storage temperature, pH, light, oxygen, enzymes, proteins, and metallic ions [1-3]. A strategy to improve the stability and bioavailability of sensitive bioactive compounds including folic acid is encapsulation. Recently double emulsions have been received increased interest. Double emulsions (also duplex or multiple emulsions) are emulsions of emulsions such as an oil-in-water-in-oil (O1/W/O2) emulsion or a water-in-oil-in-water (W1/O/W2) emulsion. In the latter case, water droplets (W1) are dispersed in a larger oil droplet (O) which in turn is dispersed in a continuous aqueous phase (W2). There are two different interfacial layers in this type of emulsion: the W1-O interface surrounding the inner water droplets, and the O-W2 interface surrounding the oil droplets. Consequently, two different types of emulsifier are usually needed to stabilize W1/O/W2 emulsions: an oil-soluble emulsifier for the inner water droplets and a water-soluble emulsifier for the oil droplets. Due to their increased interfacial area, these double emulsions have a lower thermodynamic stability than single emulsions. In addition, the prepared double emulsions are susceptible to break-down (to become single emulsions) during processing, among other mechanisms by the migration of water between the inner and the outer aqueous phases [4-6]. Although, double emulsions are less stable than single emulsions, they have some potential advantages. The inner water phase can be used as a carrier of flavors, aromas, colors, preservatives, antimicrobials, vitamins, minerals, polyphenols, amino acids, bioactive proteins, enzymes, or peptides, keeping them apart from the continuous aqueous phase (Assadpour et al., 2016). Entrapment of these ingredients can protect them from environmental effects; be used as delivery systems; and mask undesired sensory attributes [7-9]. Therefore, it has been some investigations of double emulsion delivery systems to protect the bioactive components from detrimental effects. Research over recent decades has shown that low or inadequate folate concentrations may contribute to some malfunctions and disorders [10]. In many countries, particularly the developing populations, people suffer from folate deficiency. Cereal flours have been a primary candidate for fortification as they are consumed by most of the people [11-13]. Fortification with folic acid (FA) has some possible limitations since added vitamin may be lost during processing and handling due to its high sensitivity to heat, oxidation, pH, and other environmental conditions. Due to its properties as a vitamin and medicinal compound, FA must be protected against environmental conditions and should have a targeted release. There are several ways to encapsulate and protect
hydrophilic bioactive components such as FA including liposomes, multiple emulsions, solid fat particles, biopolymer complexes, niosomes, and biologically derived systems [14-16]. Whey protein concentrate (WPC) is a mixture of different globular proteins including βlactoglobulin with molecular weight of 18.3×103 g/mol being the most dominant followed by αlactalbumin [17]. The ability of whey proteins to form stable emulsions depends on emulsion composition (such as pH, mineral content, salt, sugar, surfactant and polysaccharide content) and environmental conditions (temperature and pressure) [15]. Polysaccharides increase the stability of emulsions by enhancing the viscosity of the aqueous phase [18]. Pectin is one of the most popular polysaccharides which has been widely used as gelling, thickening and stabilizing agents in the food and pharmaceutical industries for many years. Pectin is extracted from plant cell walls, especially from apple pomace, citrus fruits, and sugar beet root. It is a family of galacturonic acidrich polysaccharides including, rhamnogalacturonan I, homogalacturonan, and the substituted galacturonan rhamnogalacturonan II (RG-II), and xylogalacturonan (XGA) [19]. Complex of protein-polysaccharide in appropriate conditions in terms of concentration, ratio of protein: polysaccharide, pH, ionic strength, and temperature could result in enhanced stability of emulsions [20]. In fact, this complex is formed through covalent and/or electrostatic bonds. One of the main problems in W1/O/W2 double emulsions is the release of bioactive ingredients within the internal aqueous phase into external aqueous phase. In these emulsions, there are two general release processes [9,21-23]: firstly, the release due to coalescence of droplets within the internal phase and destruction of the interfacial film between internal and external phases; secondly, transfer of solubilized ingredients within the internal aqueous phase (W1) through the interfacial layer without any physical breakage of this layer and mostly by means of diffusion into external phase (W2) due to driving force of concentration gradient and Laplace pressure gradient among dispersed droplets. Also, it is possible to consider different diffusion mechanisms such as (1) diffusion of hydrophilic ingredients into oil phase, (2) diffusion from thin layer of liquid interface membrane, (3) solubilization of encapsulated ingredients in reverse micelles and diffusion of micelles into oil phase. Mathematical modeling of release for bioactive ingredients could provide useful information about mass transfer and chemical processes responsible for transfer of bioactive components [24]. It also reveals what is the influence of important parameters such as morphology and loading of encapsulated bioactives on the release rate. Therefore, it is possible to have a good prediction of the release and find the optimized conditions with minimum experimental data. There have been some good studies on the release kinetics of food bioactive ingredients and nutraceuticals from encapsulated environments. For instance, Fathi et al (2012) evaluated release of hesperidin from
solid lipid nano-particles in simulated gastrointestinal conditions and found Pepas model as the best model describing the release behavior of hesperidin. Alvarado, et al., (2009) investigated release of iron from W/O/W double emulsions stabilized by protein-polysaccharide complexes by different models of Higuchi, Pepas, Hixson-Crowell, zero order and first order kinetics [25]. In the present work, the release of folic acid was studied from spray dried powder particles containing W/O/W double emulsions stabilized by pectin-whey protein complex as a function of pH, surfactant type, and number of layers to make double emulsions. Our main goal was to produce a stable nano-carrier for folic acid through W/O/W multiple emulsions protected by functional biopolymers (pectin/WPC) with controlled release. It was expected that formulation of W1/O/W2 emulsions containing a primary W1/O nano-emulsion (with smaller droplets), and by applying complexes of WPC/pectin in the outer phase could control transport of folic acid (known to be very sensitive to environmental conditions) from the inner phase into the outer aqueous phase of W1/O/W2 emulsions and preserve its integrity during the shelf life. 2. Materials and methods Folic acid (purity>97%, molecular weight 441.4) and Span 80 (sorbitan mono oleate) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co. (St. Louis, MO), and Merck Chemicals Co. (Germany), respectively. PGPR (polyglycerol polyricinoleate, E476)) was kindly donated by Palsgaard, Denmark. Canola oil was purchased from a local market. Double distilled water was used for preparing all emulsions. Whey protein concentrate (80% protein) and maltodextrin were obtained from Arla (Denmark) and Qinhuangdao starch Co. (DE 16-20, China), respectively. Citrus pectin with a degree of methyl esterification of 71.1% and galacturonic acid >65% was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co. (St. Louis, MO). All other chemicals used in this study were of analytical grade.

sections.heading: 2.1. Nano-emulsion production
sections.text: W/O nano-emulsions were prepared by spontaneous emulsification according to our previously mentioned procedures for making W/O emulsions [26]. Briefly, aqueous phase was prepared by mixing FA solution and Span 80 using a magnetic stirrer (IKA, Germany) at 1000 rpm and then added drop wise to oil phase while magnetically stirring. The formulation was composed of 76:12:12% of canola oil, surfactant (Span or PGPR), and folic acid solution (with a concentration of 3 mg FA/mL in phosphate buffer at pH= 9), respectively.

sections.heading: 2.2. Biopolymer solution preparation
sections.text:
Pectin powder (0.1, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0 g) was dissolved in boiling deionized water to prepare 100 g pectin solutions. At the same time, different aqueous solutions of whey protein concentrate were prepared by dispersing required amounts of WPC powder (as shown in Table 1) into deionized
water to obtain 100 g solutions containing 0.02% sodium azide as an antimicrobial agent. Solutions were gently stirred for at least 30 min on a magnetic stirrer. Then, pectin and WPC solutions were mixed together and stored overnight at room temperature for complete hydration of biopolymers. For increasing dry matter of the feed into spray dryer, 30 g maltodextrin solution (Brix= 50) was added into mixed biopolymer solutions and their pH was adjusted to predetermined pH values using HCL and NaOH (0.1 M).

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of W1/O/W2 double emulsions
sections.text: W/O/W emulsions were prepared in two-step, according to Faridi et al., (2015). Frist, primary W/O nano-emulsions were produced by the formulation procedure described in section 2.1. Then, W/O/W double emulsions were prepared by gradually adding W/O nano-emulsions into the outer aqueous phase of mixed biopolymer solutions (WPC/pectin/maltodextrin) while blending by a homogenizer (Heidolph Silentcrusher, Germany) at 12000 rpm for 5 minutes at 10oC, and then these coarse emulsions were further emulsified using mentioned homogenizer (15000 rpm for 8 minutes at 10oC). The composition of W/O/W multiple emulsions is given in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.4. Droplet size measurement
sections.text: Droplet size of nano- and double emulsions were analyzed using a dynamic light scattering method (Zetasizer Nano Zs, Malvern Instrument, Malvern, UK). To avoid multiple scattering, all samples diluted using 0.1% SDS. For microstructure analysis, some images were through a Zeiss optical microscope (Germany) and analyzed by Image J software [27]. The analysis of the sample related to Treatment No. 1 is shown in Fig. 1.

sections.heading: 2.5. Spray drying of double emulsions
sections.text: The infeed double emulsions were transformed into encapsulated powders in a lab spray drier (Model SP1500, Fanyuan Instrument Co., Shanghai, China) equipped with a pressure air atomizing nozzle at 2.5 bar air pressure, inlet air temperature of 180 ± 5oC, and outlet air temperature of 90 ± 5oC with a feed flow rate of 450 mL/h. The dried powder was collected and stored in dark bottle, air tight containers at 4oC until further analysis.

sections.heading: 2.6. Release analysis and modeling of folic acid
sections.text:
For determination of folic acid release from internal aqueous phase into external phase, 1.0 g of encapsulated FA powder was dispersed in 50 mL aqueous solutions of predetermined pH values (4, 7, 11) prepared with phosphate buffer. Then, these suspensions were placed on a magnetic stirrer at 37oC (human body temperature) and stirred at 750 rpm for different time intervals from 5 to 60 min. Afterwards, 0.5 g of each sample was taken out and filtered using Whatman filter paper
No. 41. After adding 10 mL ethanol, 7 mL hexane and 3 mL phosphate buffer (pH=9.5), These solutions were vortexed for 2 min and centrifuged at 3500 rpm for 20 min. The folic acid content was determined spectrophotometrically at 282.5 nm [28]. The release kinetics of folic acid was calculated using experimental models as below [29]: Qt = Q0 + k0t Zero order Log Ct = Log C0- k1t/2.303 First order Qt=kh×t 1/2 Higuchi (C0) 1/3 - (Ct) 1/3 = kHCt Hixson-Crowell Where k is the model constant, t is time, Qt is the released concentration of folic acid at time t, Q0 is the initial concentration of folic acid within solutions (usually Q0=0), Ct is the remaining concentration of folic acid within capsules after time t, and C0 is the initial concentration of folic acid within capsules.

sections.heading: 2.7. Scanning electron microscopy of encapsulated powders
sections.text: The nano-encapsulated powders were sprinkled onto a two-sided adhesive tape and then coated with a thin layer of gold. Morphological features of particles were then observed by a field emission scanning electron microscope (S-4160 Cold Field-Emission SEM, Hitachi, Tokyo, Japan) with an accelerated voltage of 320 kV and photographed at 6000.

sections.heading: 2.8. FTIR analysis
sections.text: The structure analysis of the WPC–pectin samples was examined by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR). The IR spectra of the samples were recorded by FT-IR spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, japan) using attenuated total reflection technique. The spectrum was scanned in transmission mode from 400 to 4500 cm wavenumber range. The dry samples were blended with KBr powder and pressed into a disk before spectrum acquisition.

sections.heading: 2.9. Statistical analysis
sections.text: According to Table 1, four different treatments were designed and the experiments were all carried out in triplicate. The collected data were analyzed through SPSS version 21 (IBM, USA) and the graphs were drawn by Microsoft Excel (2010).

sections.heading: 3.1. Folic acid release profile and modeling
sections.text:
Figures 2-5 show the folic acid release profiles from spray dried powder particles composed of double emulsions made with either pectin-whey protein concentrate or WPC alone with different concentrations of folic acid and two surfactants of Span and PGPR.
For two layered pectin-WPC formulations, the release rate in first 15-30 min appeared to follow the faster kinetics, depending on pH. In general, the release rate was higher at alkaline pH which could be attributed to the faster dissolution of applied WPC in alkaline conditions and release of folic acid from the surface of nano-carriers. Since the solubility of WPC is lowest in its isoelectric point (pH=4-5)[22,30], the release of folic acid was minimum at pH=4 as can be seen in Figures 2- 5. In fact, in these conditions, encapsulated powder particles form aggregates and precipitate out of the solution which makes it very difficult for the internal encapsulated folic acid to dissolve and release out of the capsules. This is quite desirable since the main goal of nutraceuticals and drug delivery is to pass the encapsulated ingredients from acidic conditions of stomach without any noticeable loss and release of bioactive [31,32]. As it has been revealed by release model parameters in Fig. 3 (also shown in Table 2), k value of zero order model was 2.057, 4.771, and 17.114 at pH=4, 7, and 11, respectively. Other evaluated models show the same trend. In other words, release rate at pH=11 was 4 times higher than pH=7 and 8 times higher than pH=4. Therefore, targeted delivery of folic acid into intestine which has alkaline conditions is achievable and successful while there is minimum release in acidic conditions of pH. When looking at Fig. 4, it could be seen that there is no difference in release rate between pH=4 and pH=11; by comparing the constant k values of the models. While the rate of release in pH=7 is almost 5 times higher than acidic or alkaline conditions. The main difference in this formulation and the one in Fig. 3 is the applied surfactant within internal nano-emulsion of prepared double emulsions which is PGPR in this case compared with Span in the previous case. It reveals that changing surfactant type in preparation of nano-scale delivery systems of nutraceuticals and drugs has a profound influence on the release profiles which could be attributed to the native properties of the formulation ingredients [23,33,34]. This could be probably due to lower stability of PGPR in acidic conditions compared with Span which results in flocculation and coalescence of emulsion droplets and higher release of folic acid into external aqueous phase. PGPR contains a hydrophilic poly-glycerol head group and interesterified ricinoleic fatty acids as the hydrophobic tail (Massel et al., 2015). It is more branched and heavier than Span which is a sorbitan mono oleate. The k values confirm this difference too; for instance, when evaluating zero order release model for Fig. 3 (formulation containing Span), at pH=4 the k value was 2.057, while in the same situation for Fig. 4 (formulation containing PGPR), the k value was 3.200 which means the release rate is approximately 57% higher than its Span counterpart. Also at pH=11, the k value was 17.114 and 3.543 for Span and PGPR formulations, respectively revealing almost 383% higher release of folic acid for Span nano-delivery system at alkaline conditions which is totally desirable.
Therefore, it can be concluded that nano-capsules formulated with Span showed a better release profile, since lower burst release was observed in acidic conditions and about 78 % of its folic acid load was released during the 60 min release time at alkaline conditions while for the formulation with PGPR, only 48% of folic acid release happened at the same conditions. When comparing two-layered capsules of pectin-WPC (Fig. 3) with single layered WPC nanodelivery systems (Fig. 5), almost similar release profiles of folic acid is observable with a higher release rate at alkaline conditions (pH=11) and the minimum release at acidic conditions (pH=4). But the release rates for these two systems are not equal. For single WPC formulations, higher k values have been calculated at pH= 4 and pH=7 and smaller k values at pH=11. In other words, at alkaline conditions, release rate of pectin-WPC was higher with a k=17.114 compared with WPC alone with a k=6.85; i.e., almost 2.5 higher release rate for two-layered encapsulation system. This could be due to detrimental effect of pectin on pectin-WPC networks at higher pH values which results in more and quicker release of folic acid from internal nano-emulsion of double emulsions into external aqueous phase. While in acidic conditions, the role of WPC is dominant by precipitating at its isoelectric point and inhibiting the release of folic acid in both pectin-WPC and single WPC formulations which could be confirmed by their similar k values (Table 2).
In order to select the best release model using zero-order, first-order, Higuchi, and Hixson-Crowell models, model parameter were determined and are listed in Table 2 along with their corresponding correlation coefficients. For almost all samples, based on their correlation coefficients, the best modeling was performed in alkaline conditions. Among different formulations, it was revealed that single WPC nano-capsules had the best fitting of their experimental release data and 4 evaluated models. The values of R2 for all models were found to be similar, betokened the release phenomenon is mainly governed by combination of both Fickian diffusion and dissolution mechanism.

sections.heading: 3.2. Encapsulated powder morphology
sections.text:
Fig. 6 reveals the SEM microphotographs of the powders containing folic acid within internal nano-emulsion phase of double emulsions. Observations with SEM confirmed the presence of surface dents and wrinkles in powders obtained by pectin-WPC matrix (Fig. SP1 and SP2) containing Span as the surfactant. This structure can allow higher air permeability into powders, reducing the protection of the encapsulated ingredient [35,36]. While at the same time, due to higher surface area, a higher solubility and release is predictable confirming the release results mentioned in previous section.
The powders produced with double emulsions containing PGPR (Fig. 6 PGP) and single layered WPC emulsions containing Span (Fig. 6 WPC) presented a spherical shape. Particularly, powder containing WPC alone as outer wall material of W/O/W multiple emulsions had less surface dents and pores compared with other sample which could be correlated with its low release rates. It could be concluded that powders obtained from two-layer W/O/W emulsions of pectin-WPC had much shrinkage and surface dents and pores probably due to different thermal behavior of these two biopolymers during spray drying. While samples made with single WPC came up with smooth surfaces, no cracks, and no dents which could have better protection of encapsulated bioactive component and higher encapsulation efficiency, although no judgment about their release behavior could be done.

sections.heading: 3.3. FTIR analysis
sections.text:
FTIR studies were conducted as a supplementary technique to find out any interaction between applied biopolymers and folic acid. Due to the interaction of carboxyl groups presented in pectin with amino groups presented in the whey protein, it could be expected appearance of amide groups in charged complexs of pectin-WPC [14]. Therefore, FT-IR analysis was carried out to confirm the formation of amide in the charged complex of WPC and pectin for folic acid-loaded encapsulated powders (Fig. 7). Pure folic acid infrared spectrum showed several identical absorption bands including OH, NH, C=N, C=O agreed with literatures [37]. For example, phenyl and pterin ring at 1455-1518 cm-1, NH bending at 1543 cm-1, C=C aromatic at 1579 cm-1, C=N at 1668 cm-1, and OH carboxylic groups at 3100-3500 cm-1. The FTIR spectra of pure WPC powders revealed the presence of characteristic functional groups at 1631, 1509, 1420, and 1039 cm-1 corresponding to the stretching of C=O, and the bending of NH, CH, and CN bonds, respectively (Faridi et al., 2015). On the other hand, the spectrum of folic acid loaded pectin-WPC encapsulated powders exhibited a sharp band at 992 cm-1 which is related to the C=O stretching and indicates the formation of WPC/pectin complex. In addition, the entire charged complex showed a peak at 1629 cm-1 which could be the amide bond formed between the amino groups of WPC and carboxyl groups of pectin. This cross-linking of nanoparticle-loaded WPC/pectin powders would led to the formation of a double-layer structure via establishment of net charge of biopolymers between the carboxylate ions of pectin on the amide groups of WPC (Lutz et al., 2009). This phenomenon most probably accounts for the decreased transmittance of the peaks related to the asymmetrical vibrations (at 1629 cm-1) in the spectrum of cross-linked encapsulated powders. In agreement, Chen et al. [38]
and Faridi et al. (2015) reported the bio fabrication of stable WPC/pectin complex coacervations with new characteristics and an identical band at 1108 cm-1 and 1557 cm-1.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: In this study, we evaluated the release profile and trends for spray dried encapsulated powders of folic acid within W/O/W multiple emulsions. A complex double layer biopolymer of pectin and WPC or a single layer of WPC was applied in the external aqueous phase of double emulsions and the internal aqueous phases was composed of either Span or PGPR surfactant. Another variable was pH of the release medium. It was found that the most affecting parameter on the release of folic acid was the surfactant type within the internal dispersed phase so that Span resulted in the lowest and highest release rate in acidic (pH=4) and alkaline (pH=11) conditions, respectively. Also, there was a perfect fitting of the release models on single layered WPC capsules with a high correlation coefficient. By evaluating the microstructure of final powders, we observed that those made with a complex of pectin-WPC had wrinkles and dents at the surface of their particles and samples from WPC alone, had smooth surfaces with spherical particles.

sections.heading: 5. Acknowledgement
sections.text: It is necessary to appreciate Iran Nanotechnology Initiative Council (INIC) for their financial support.

metadata.abstractText: Our main goal was to evaluate release kinetics of nano-encapsulated folic acid within a double W1/O/W2 emulsion. First, W1/O nano-emulsions loaded with folic acid were prepared and reemulsified into an aqueous phase (W2) containing single whey protein concentrate (WPC) layer or double layer complex of WPC-pectin to form W1/O/W2 emulsions. Final double emulsions were spray dried and their microstructure was analyzed in terms of scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). Also the release trends of folic acid were determined and fitted with experimental models of zero and first order, Higuchi, and HixsonCrowell. It was revealed that folic acid nano-capsules made with Span as the surfactant had the lowest release rate in acidic conditions (pH=4) and highest release in the alkaline conditions (pH=11). The best model fitting for folic acid release data was observed for single layer WPC encapsulated powders with the highest R. Our FTIR data showed there was no chemical interaction between WPC and pectin in double layered capsules and based on SEM results, single WPC layered capsules resulted in smooth and uniform particles which by incorporating pectin, some wrinkles and shrinkage were found in the surface of spray dried powder particles.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
